doc.previous: Censuses do more than just count people They typically collect information about families or households in addition to individual characteristics such as age sex marital status literacy education employment status and occupation and geographical location They may also collect data on migration or place of birth or of previous residence language religion nationality or ethnicity or race and citizenship In countries in which the vital registration system may be incomplete the censuses are also used as a direct source of information about fertility and mortality for example the censuses of the People s Republic of China gather information on births and deaths that occurred in the 18 months immediately preceding the census
